<!--StartFragment-->

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><i><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Note</span></i></b><i><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">:
This is a copy of the original that used to live at
http://www.bluetail.com/~joe/vol1/v1_oo.html</span></i><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">)<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">When
I was first introduced to the idea of OOP I was skeptical but didn’t know why -
it just felt “wrong”. After its introduction OOP became very popular (I will
explain why later) and criticising OOP was rather like “swearing in church”.
OOness became something that every respectable language just had to have.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">As
Erlang became popular we were often asked “Is Erlang OO” - well, of course the
true answer was “No of course not” - but we didn’t to say this out loud - so we
invented a serious of ingenious ways of answering the question that were
designed to give the impression that Erlang was (sort of) OO (If you waved your
hands a lot) but not really (If you listened to what we actually said, and read
the small print <i>carefully</i>).<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">At
this point I am reminded of the keynote speech of the then boss of IBM in
France who addressed the audience at the 7th IEEE Logic programming conference
in Paris. IBM prolog had added a lot of OO extensions, when asked why he
replied:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">“<i>Our
customers wanted OO prolog so we made OO prolog</i>”<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">I
remember thinking “how simple, no qualms of conscience, no soul-searching, no
asking "Is this the right thing to do” …<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:15.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;color:#094EC0;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">Why OO sucks<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">My
principle objection to OOP goes back to the basic ideas involved, I will
outline some of these ideas and my objections to them.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:15.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;color:#094EC0;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">Objection 1 - Data structure and functions should not be
bound together<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Objects
bind functions and data structures together in indivisible units. I think this
is a fundamental error since functions and data structures belong in totally
different worlds. Why is this?<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">*Functions
do things. They have inputs and outputs. The inputs and outputs are data
structures, which get changed by the functions. In most languages functions are
built from sequences of imperatives: “Do this and then that …” to understand
functions you have to understand the order in which things get done (In lazy
FPLs and logical languages this restriction is relaxed).<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Data structures just are. They don’t do anything. They are intrinsically
declarative. “Understanding” a data structure is a lot easier than
“understanding” a function.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Functions
are understood as black boxes that transform inputs to outputs. If I understand
the input and the output then I have understood the function. <i>This does not
mean to say that I could have written the function</i>.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Functions
are usually “understood” by observing that they are the things in a
computational system whose job is to transfer data structures of type T1 into
data structure of type T2.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top:0cm;margin-right:6.75pt;margin-bottom:
6.75pt;margin-left:6.75pt;text-indent:-6.8pt;mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Since functions and data structures are
completely different types of animal it is fundamentally incorrect to lock them
up in the same cage.</span></b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt"><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:15.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;color:#094EC0;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">Objection 2 - Everything has to be an object<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Consider
“time”. In an OO language “time” has to be an object. But in a non OO language
a “time” is a instance of a data type. For example, in Erlang there are lots of
different varieties of time, these can be clearly and unambiguously specified
using type declarations, as follows:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
day() = 1..31.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
month() = 1..12.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
year() = int().<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
hour() = 1..24.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
minute() = 1..60.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
second() = 1..60.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
abstime() = {abstime, year(), month(), day(), hour(), min(), sec()}.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">-deftype
hms() = {hms, hour(), min(), sec()}.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Courier",serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Courier;mso-font-kerning:0pt">...<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Note
that these definitions do not belong to any particular object. they are
ubiquitous and data structures representing times can be manipulated by any
function in the system.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">There
are no associated methods.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:15.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;color:#094EC0;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">Objection 3 - In an OOPL data type definitions are spread
out all over the place<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">In
an OOPL data type definitions belong to objects. So I can’t find all the data
type definition in one place. In Erlang or C I can define all my data types in
a single include file or data dictionary. In an OOPL I can’t - the data type
definitions are spread out all over the place.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Let
me give an example of this. Suppose I want to define a ubiquitous data
structure. <i>ubiquitous</i> data type is a data type that occurs “all over the
place” in a system.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">As
lisp programmers have know for a long time it is better to have a smallish
number of ubiquitous data types and a large number of small functions that work
on them, than to have a large number of data types and a small number of
functions that work on them.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">A
ubiquitous data structure is something like a linked list, or an array or a
hash table or a more advanced object like a time or date or filename.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">In
an OOPL I have to choose some base object in which I will define the ubiquitous
data structure, all other objects that want to use this data structure must
inherit this object. Suppose now I want to create some “time” object, where
does this belong and in which object…<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:15.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;color:#094EC0;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">Objection 4 - Objects have private state<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">State
is the root of all evil. In particular functions with side effects should be
avoided.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">While
state in programming languages is undesirable, in the real world state abounds.
I am highly interested in the state of my bank account, and when I deposit or
withdraw money from my bank I expect the state of my bank account to be
correctly updated.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Given
that state exists in the real world what facilities should programming language
provide for dealing with state?<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">OOPLs say “hide the state from the programmer”. The states is hidden and
visible only through access functions.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Conventional programming languages (C, Pascal) say that the visibility of
state variables is controlled by the scope rules of the language.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Pure declarative languages say that there is no state.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">The
global state of the system is carried into all functions and comes out from all
functions. Mechanisms like monads (for FPLs) and DCGs (logic languages) are
used to hide state from the programmer so they can program “as if state didn’t
matter” but have full access to the state of the system should this be
necessary.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">The
“hide the state from the programmer” option chosen by OOPLs is the worse
possible choice. Instead of revealing the state and trying to find ways to
minimise the nuisance of state, they hide it away.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:15.5pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;color:#094EC0;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">Why OO was popular?<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Reason 1 - It was thought to be easy to learn.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Reason 2 - It was thought to make code reuse easier.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Reason 3 - It was hyped.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;mso-pagination:
widow-orphan;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:11.0pt 36.0pt;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none"><!--[if !supportLists]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">•<span style="font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">  
</span></span><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;
font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:
0pt">Reason 4 - It created a new software industry.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">I
see no evidence of 1 and 2. Reasons 3 and 4 seem to be the driving force behind
the technology. If a language technology is so bad that it creates a new
industry to solve problems of its own making then it must be a good idea for
the guys who want to make money.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:13.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica",sans-serif;
mso-bidi-font-family:Helvetica;mso-font-kerning:0pt">This is is the real
driving force behind OOPs.</span><span lang="EN-US"><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<!--EndFragment-->
